text:
I think that in-running seasonality <@U03FS7KM2NL> is due to the longer distances.   

For what it's worth Imo the reasons for the decline are manyfold, innovators (like TPD) have been more interested in wooing us than generating new customers, lack of interest in the affected sports, greater competition for the leisure £, a decade+ of wage/inflation disparity, lack of imagination in the way betting is presented, probably others too.

The question is, will the decline bottom out before it becomes unsustainable.

elements.text: I think that in-running seasonality

is due to the longer distances.   

For what it's worth Imo the reasons for the decline are manyfold, innovators (like TPD) have been more interested in wooing us than generating new customers, lack of interest in the affected sports, greater competition for the leisure £, a decade+ of wage/inflation disparity, lack of imagination in the way betting is presented, probably others too.

The question is, will the decline bottom out before it becomes unsustainable.

text:
I'd say <@UEA14GBRR> that TPD is the only innovation (can't think of any others). BHA seem useless and have no ideas and their premierisation thing seems to get a lot of stick. I think that the younger generation just have so many options for things to be interested in these days and it seems very understandable that they are not so interested in racing - particularly if you add on the way that gambling is demonised these days. Then factor in affordability checks and the fact that a lot of people have been shafted by inflation, energy bill rises and general cost of living and it paints a dreary picture of things to come.
Then you hear about owners getting pissed off due to the prize money being so low and bookies complaining about the cost of media rights....
I guess we will all try to wring as much out of it as we can but you are spot on in saying that diversification might be needed. People are resourceful though and adapt to the situation. People coped with the changes caused by addition of XM and PC not me I hasten to add) but kept going. You can still make money from low volume markets at the end of the day and you can only play the cards you are dealt.

Shame we can't bookmark this thread and review a year from now to see if the decline has worsened. I suspect though, that the people doing well now will still be doing well then.

text: You should <@UEA14GBRR> but UKGC does not agree unfortunately. If push ever comes to shove for me, I would be willing to share a screenshot of total account balance on my bank accounts and that is it. I'd never give over anything more than that.

text: <@U05N9773A23> I am not against the project at all. I just think the word crypto is a big red flag to a lot of people. I don't know for sure but I envisage that I make my profit from recreational punters or people who have bought a "trading" e-book from the likes of Tony Hargraves or Caan Berry. A crypto based exchange would be a good thing IMO but the subset of people using it would be relatively tiny. But that is all just my opinion and doesn't count for s*it really.

text:
IMO, the last decade or so has been a steady decline in exchange betting in general as most of the younger generation are less interested in "old man" sports like racing. Of the many "gamblers" I've worked with over the years, there are basically 3 distinct groups:
1. Those that "like a bet" who are seemingly obsessed with accumulators and have near zero understanding of the probability of picking 7 correct football scores. They're also the type of people who buy £20 worth of scratch cards several times a week because they "won" £50 last month. I've introduced quite a few to the betfair exchange, but they ultimately end up going to the sports book or casino games because they want big returns for their £10 bet.
2. The slightly more educated "investors" who understand that a 10% ROI is good but aren't interested in short term betting markets. They're generally into Forex/crypto/poker/etc, where "skill" is required. With the advent of low/zero charge stock apps like Trading212, etc I know of quite a few that are fairly clueless but have the buffer of being able to wait for longer term recovery when they get it wrong, so as far as they're concerned they're semi professional.
3. Those with a genuine interest racing/football/etc, but they're going to the meetings and having a punt for fun and aren't bothered if they lose.
The rest of us degens have spent years doing ok but the hours spent getting there probably equate to minimum wage. But we're enjoying the challenge. :grinning:

Those that "like a bet" who are seemingly obsessed with accumulators and have near zero understanding of the probability of picking 7 correct football scores. They're also the type of people who buy £20 worth of scratch cards several times a week because they "won" £50 last month. I've introduced quite a few to the betfair exchange, but they ultimately end up going to the sports book or casino games because they want big returns for their £10 bet.

The slightly more educated "investors" who understand that a 10% ROI is good but aren't interested in short term betting markets. They're generally into Forex/crypto/poker/etc, where "skill" is required. With the advent of low/zero charge stock apps like Trading212, etc I know of quite a few that are fairly clueless but have the buffer of being able to wait for longer term recovery when they get it wrong, so as far as they're concerned they're semi professional.
Those with a genuine interest racing/football/etc, but they're going to the meetings and having a punt for fun and aren't bothered if they lose.
The rest of us degens have spent years doing ok but the hours spent getting there probably equate to minimum wage. But we're enjoying the challenge.

text: Forex is a no go, crypto is a maybe if you have actual trading/quant experience, but there’s always a chance you build out a model and get kicked off because of regulation changes. You have to think what specific edge you might have, tower dominate cross exchange arbs and general HFT crypto, there’s probably money to be made on hours to days horizon but would need experience doing that or something similar. If you somehow have access to an exchange that firms can’t get access too (for whatever reason) then that could be an edge. Otherwise it’s tough.

elements.text: Forex is a no go, crypto is a maybe if you have actual trading/quant experience, but there’s always a chance you build out a model and get kicked off because of regulation changes. If you somehow have access to an exchange that firms can’t get access too (for whatever reason) then that could be an edge. Otherwise it’s tough.

text: There maybe money to be made on weird decentralized trading protocols but there’s a large rug pull risk and may take a lot of work getting your code to interface with them relative to the volume. There have also been index rebal style trades in the past where I think some automated fund/contract would be forced to trade at certain times of the year and could be preempted.
